values:
is it bad for everyone
and if so, wholly bad?

see, my medicines are also
rat poison, and every
medicine might give you
headaches, nausea, dizziness as it
clears your arteries or your mind.

could this be just another daily dose
another thing to strengthen you
in only pointed ways?

More and more frequently the edges
of me dissolve and I become
a wish to assimilate the world, including
you, if possible through the skin
like a cool plant's tricks with oxygen
and live by a harmless green burning.

I would not consume
you or ever
finish, you would still be there
surrounding me, complete
as the air.

Unfortunately I don't have leaves.
Instead I have eyes
and teeth and other non-green
things which rule out osmosis.

So be careful, I mean it,
I give you fair warning:

This kind of hunger draws
everything into its own
space; nor can we
talk it all over, have a calm
rational discussion.

There is no reason for this, only
a starved dog's logic about bones.

In a fever I thought to myself that I am insane, certifiable, and I grinned.  The simple-minded like to ask if crazy people know they are crazy, do insane people think they are insane?  What difference does such a pedestrian question make?  How will its answer make you feel better?

I grinned and colors looked brighter and I felt freer thinking to myself, "I am insane.  I do not belong here, the world is unsuitable for me because I am unsuitable for the world."  All burdens of social expectations were lifted.  Why be polite, why eat dinner, why say goodbye before leaving, why pretend?

It is a wave that happens, feeling completely separate from humanity, feeling above it, empowered and superior.  Or, if not superior, different.  And I went to the computer, listened appropriately to a song named "Insanity" and realized again how petty, how very ultimately human, to doubt one's own sanity.  A man beats on drums and crowds yell and flail about thinking, "I, too, feel insane, I too do not fit."

But some of us wear it on our faces and some of us sink it inside ourselves and only wonder in the darkest, most sober nights, am I unhinged?  What freedom.

You can't unwrite letters.  I scroll down this page and see love letters written by a version of myself that is no more than shedded skin on the side of the highway.  I am ashamed of them, for they are really love letters to myself, to my ability with words, to a romanticized notion of what love is, what my love for Don was, and so forth.  They are permanent, though, they cannot be destroyed even if I burn them, and I do not think I want to burn them.

I do not write love letters, now.  I wrote them for Ian, and for Don, in the twilight of our romances, when I was grasping for some kind of meaning, some way to feel fulfilled in a situation that is inherently incapable of fulfilling me.  Now, I want to write love letters to myself.  She is the one who needs them, the one who should be benefitting from my natural talents.  But I starve her for affection and she pours herself, like water, into the arms of men, their methods of praising and caring - she is weak or strong or cuddly or standoffish, she is the shape that expands to fit the amount of affection available to her - solid, slippery, full, thin, she is the same shape as what is available to her.

And there are ways that another human being cannot give her affection, and ways men cannot give her affection, she does not know how to hold herself, hold herself up into one shape, her shape.  Be like water, be like water, but you'll seep into floorboards, carpets, you will become a mire and be walked upon, where there is no dignity even if there is an enlightening view.

made of gilded stone, your hands are all that's free and they
are burdened.

your only mouth is fingers licking lettered keys, slobbering dry through sentences,
nimble but unsubtle.

the moon threw itself at us 
       sluiced by blinds 
a white dress 
a lithe body, limp back over a 
       tan stone arm, in ecstacy 

to be inside that dress, 
      that heartbeat, that cell of time,  
abolished poetry.

People have said that I'm a writer, that I have a way with words.  This may be the case.

But words are cheap.  Even the greatest words written by the greatest men are cheap, simple, and manipulative.  They are grunts we created ages ago in order to avoid the chaos of existence - at their best they convey technical information accurately and at their worst they abstract, compartmentalize, and dilute our very being.  I find that they almost always fall short of what I need them to do, and as a result I am starting to abandon them whereas I once embraced them to a fault.

There are things we say with our eyes, and with our bodies, that I hope words never touch.

[insert snarky remark to offset the serious tone of this message],
Vi

Once when I was growing up, I took a trip to the beach with a girl who lived in my neighborhood.  I did not know her very well, but the trip sounded like fun so I decided to go along.  Near the beach was a forested area and in that area of the forest was a creek full of tadpoles.  Being quite young and still amazed at the variety of life on earth, I began collecting them to take home.  I got them back to my house safely and my mother helped me set up a fishbowl habitat for them.

I took them into school once a few of them had started growing legs.  I was the hit of first grade with those little guys, and although I thought they were astounding, I did not name them.  They were just, collectively, "the tadpoles," and even though I would sit and watch them individually move about, I never thought to actually name them.

At some point, at my brother's insistence I'm sure, I decided to name them.  At which point they began to die off.  At the moment, they are still in a shoebox buried in my mother's yard, their names forgotten and interred with their little leg bones.

===============

There was a night when my mother could hear a strange yipping come from under the house.  She urged my father to investigate and when he did he discovered the runt of a neighborhood cat's litter.  He pulled it out from under the house and, as a family, we cleaned it up and took it to the vet.  He was a two week old kitten, basically useless, but we were told he might be fine if we kept him warm and fed him.  All day long my brother and I played with this kitten that we knew was going to be ours.  We played with him for hours and hours and only at bedtime did my mother care to suggest we find a name for him.  We argued a bit and decided upon "Buster."  When we woke up the next morning, he had died.  His bones are somewhere near those of the tadpoles, and it still pains me to remember his name.

===============

Language is perhaps the most useful tool of society as it exists today.  Each combination of letters represents an abstraction, and arbitrarily stirs up emotions and ideas in us.  Words are self-contained little bubbles, in theory.  You can find a definitive list of other words that any given word "means."  However, they say language evolves, it is alive.  Each person who encounters a given word infuses it with the entirety of their experience.  And so, words from hundreds of years ago can reach us now and affect us, or serve as a catalyst for individuals to allow themselves to affect . . . themselves.  You see, the dictionary is a guidebook, but we all decide for ourselves what firsthand experience qualifies as "pain" or "joy."  Webster provides the borders, but each of us draws our own personal map.

We each decide when an experience is a "thing," and then consequently that that "thing" requires a name.  The list of available names for any given experience is chosen from a dictionary.  We must take the broadest possible terminology and apply it to our most specific and personal encounters with the world.  We have to borrow the "pain" and "joy" that are used indiscriminately in advertisements and as jokes and as threats by the population at large, and we have to somehow find space for our own unique pains and joys.

Like cramming -yet another- person onto a rush hour MUNI train, we make the people in our lives and the experiences in our souls uncomfortable and crowded by forcing them to all share horrendously vague terms being simultaneously used by people we hate to describe experiences we cannot understand.

I take the people I know and the things I feel and I let them wait for an empty train car.  They ride alone, they are silent, but it is they, and they alone, who fill up the space.  Nothing crowds or crushes them, no one pollutes their air space.  They remain pure and calm and unnamed.

beautiful things keep happening and i keep
ignoring them.

i think i have snared beheaded and mounted
enough beauty.

boyfriendless

i can smell my own decay
or i guess that's what that smell is
the smell of feeling alone
the smell of emptiness
the sense that this is the worst time

this is the worst time.

and there will be worse times after this one
worse smells
more pungent
stronger
harder to pin down smells
of decay
and loneliness
and fear

when everything smells.

It feels old, boring, but you can't create new feelings in yourself, only put yourself in new situations and locations and hope the chemical reaction between inner and outer worlds creates a new feeling, a new color.  And yet I go always to the same place, the beach, and am able only to reconnect with an old adolescent feeling - floating, being swept out, being wanted.  That's it. [being wanted, that is the feeling I am after]
 
The tide seduces me, steadily drawing me near and then using its foamy arms to push sand behind my ankles, to pull me in.  And what is a seduction but a persistent calling to yield, yield, as the beach, the rocks, slowly yield to the sea . . .
 
And that is why I have failed to seduce Jeremy, why I failed at Andrew and Vitaly and feel I am still failing today.  Who can be won over by an ocean ever-changing - only sixteen waves today, but six million tomorrow?  Too chaotic, I attract only daredevil surfers, I crash only on the hardest rock -- and a modest soul will always shy away unless I am calm, unassuming, serene, welcoming.  And perhaps I am, at first, but then as you come closer to me my chaos is more obvious -- waves side-swiping each other, a desperate clinging onto the shore [fingernails and teeth grating away as I hold on by them], cold, salty, as the tide comes in the waves are more aggressive, taunting, daring, angry, threatening, but made of the same stuff that first seduced you.
 
I must let some things go -- cannot rage and expect rocks to crumble immediately.  Instead of trying to crash even harder on them, I must roll out to sea.  Must be grateful for the daredevils, the surfers, the men who dare to don wetsuits.  For Don.

I endured some small collision when we last made love and there is an oval bruise ripening on my anterior right shoulder.  It is the color of drying watercolors against my skin: an aqueous splash of purple with darkened pinprick spots that bloomed into an elliptical tan and is wilting to a yellowish egg, the purplish spots now collected along the bottom.  It is small, the size of a thumbprint, I would imagine.  Well, your thumbprint - your hands and fingers are my size, feminine, and soft.

If I knew for certain that your thumb grabbing my shoulder caused this mark, that has lived almost a week on its own, I would feel compelled to bludgeon the area again, stamping the same broken blood vessel and squeezing out more colors.  I would want to see the visible proof of you, longer.

Yet, for all I know, I incurred this injury stepping into a doorframe, or leaning a funny way against a subway pole on the way to meet you.

I strode down the street: my outfit and attitude for making love one of coy confidence, and yours of boyish elusion.  As I clip-clopped toward you, our eyes caught each other and you ducked behind a concrete pillar, as though your thirty year-old frame could ever move as quickly as your mind, your body could possibly escape my gaze.  And my gait gained purpose, I became matronly, intentioned, and aggressive.  Could I have bruised myself?

You called me baby, begged me to give myself joy, held my hair, kissed my nose.  You entered me suddenly, and all at once, and we struggled.  I cannot penetrate, so I would merely deny, repel, reject, and elicit your renewed effort.  But at what point did you touch my shoulder?  I on top, you behind, when?

Afterwards, I massaged your back with my feet, skin on skin, and I looked down at the nape of your neck.

You read to me and I fell asleep watching the bridge peekaboo with me from across your deck, through the curtains.  I read to you and you fell asleep as I struggled to regain the enunciation talents of my adolescence.  I awoke to your voice, soft, at the doorway.

Did you bite me?  Let's say you bit me as you buried your face into my shoulder, exclaiming love.  That's the ticket.

I know you cannot love me as I love you - you weren't built for this strange and glorious pain.  We, too, will ripen and wilt and it will be as natural as the next thing despite all the various colors that fill our shape.  I wish always to return to the soil, to smooth consistent skin.  But at this moment, anticipating our next contact, anxious because you are leaving in merely a week, I would like to leave the littlest vein open, to keep the tiniest fissure intact, so that I might bleed for you in the way most appropriate to us: slowly, subtly, painfully, beautifully, but always beneath the surface.

Dear Mother,
 
I have not met you and yet I already admire and respect you immensely based on solely your son's recounting of your life and personality.  In particular, I look up to you for raising such a wonderful man.
 
It is difficult to produce a lovable man, I would imagine.  It is hard enough to grab one who is already part-grown and try to shape something decent out of him, let alone mold one properly from the ground up amidst the chaos of your own life.  But you, somehow, have done it.  Of course, he is only half-grown himself, still flawed and awkward and headstrong, but learning fiercely, and only getting better. 
 
I know that, as times goes by, whether he and I stay together or split apart, and whether he breaks my heart or I his, he will continue to be a good man for the rest of his life, steadily improving himself and those around him.  I know that this is true because, despite his sometimes thick head, he has the most important quality a man can have, one that is invariably the result of an extraordinary mother -- an open heart.
 
Maybe, when we finally do meet, we won't even like each other.  But even if we become the kind of domestic in-laws who spit drunken insults at each other over every Thanksgiving dinner, we will always have this one thing in common: a beautiful boy that we love the best that we can, with all that we've got, each in our own way.
 
Because you are his mother, I know full well that I will never be able to love him as much as you do.  But I hope you take it as a comfort, and not a challenge, that I am damn well going to try.
 
-Girlfriend
 
P.S. Of course, your influence might also be the source of those personality traits of his that I would rather do without, but, if you prefer, we can agree to blame those on his father.

Dear D,

Today I knew I loved you because I desperately wanted something that I've always hated.  The feeling of your stubble on my stomach's skin, when you lean against me on the sofa.  It itches, it scratches, it grates.  I've always been annoyed with it, I've always had you sit up straight, I've always put on a face of irritation to match the irritation to my skin.

But tonight, while sitting on the sofa, I remembered it, and I missed it.  And I thought, "Men are supposed to have stubble, that's how you know they're men.  What I wouldn't do to feel his stubble, right now, contrasting with my soft skin, and I would lay there, calmly accepting the scouring of your face."

And what had always been a minor annoyance became, in an instant, a representation of the entirety of love, its pain and sacrifice mixed with intimacy.  I want you home for not just all the big ways you make me happy, but for all the small ways you irritate me, too.

My love is true; come back to me.

Yours,
Vi

Dear bed,
 
 What is going on?  You have seemed so distant lately and I wish you would tell me why.  When we get close at night, you don't seem as soft, you don't welcome me as warmly.  Mere days ago, things were perfect between us: you carried me gently to sleep, you were the only place I felt relaxed, you were my sanctuary.
 
 But now, there is something missing.  Even when I am with you, I feel so alone.  Your blankets don't keep me as warm, they don't wrap around me as tightly.  I avoid you as long as possible, until sleep forces me into your arms and even then, it is a loveless embrace.
 
 I have tried to get the spark back.  I've touched parts of you I have long neglected.  I've tried every position I can conceive of.  But nothing seems to work.  You lie there physically surrendering to me, but withholding the tenderness that I need.  What is stopping you?
 
 It's him, isn't it?

To the man between my dreams:

I had just arrived at work when I heard cars pulling into the driveway.  I put down my briefcase and pulled back the curtains of the upstairs window in order to see a large shiny black pick up truck loaded with people.  I only thought I knew one person, a man, at first.  As the crowd grew, I recognized more people in it.  They were all nostalgically familiar, but I'd no idea who they actually were.  I was surrounded by a family of strangers.  I wanted badly to leave work, but there was too much to do.  I cracked the window open and watched as one of them pulled out a boombox.  I went downstairs.  A woman explained to me that this was their annual ritual, to play a particular Jethro Tull song at top volume in the early hours of the morning.  It seemed like a strange ritual, but I figured it would make more sense if I knew which song they were going to play.  I forgot about work for the moment and sat down to listen to the song, so I could identify it and solve the puzzle of this tradition, and why it would include me.  The first few notes played and then
 
There was a man leaning over me, in very sharp focus.  He was clean-shaven, wearing a dark coat that looked new and stylish.  He smiled warmly, looked me right in the eyes, and spoke to me.  I don't remember what he said, only that he was saying goodbye.  I didn't feel sad.  I wanted to know which Jethro Tull song was playing.  Everything felt like a mystery, the vague yet intimate crowd suddenly shrinking to one sharply defined man, tenderly kissing me on his way out the door.  I was suddenly very aware of my warmth, and of darkness.  I forgot about the song.  The room fell out from under me as this man alighted on my bed, for a moment, and then
 
I am not sure where I was.  There were calm waves.  I couldn't hear anything except a relentless rush of water pulsating through air.  For a moment, I thought it was music, but it was just the sounds of nature.  I existed on a plane that was out-of-body.  I organized, I strengthened, I encouraged, I enjoyed.  I do not know what, though.  Some void, some place so solely mine that it had no exposition.  It was a peaceful drift.  It was a place I could have never been if it weren't for the man who alighted on my bed, who shattered the insane puzzle of my previous life - the one full of people, but not one who knew me - and replaced it with an aimless sun-warmed float toward a meaningful morning.

the waves can't quite break against the wind.  a thin spray leaps off each rolling crest, saying no, I mustn't go.  I can't.  But most of the water makes it up the beach, the ocean foam touches the edge of drying sand, like toes hitting the poolside during timed laps, like pilgrims' hands clasping worn out sacred stones, and then it all rushes back, indistinguishable from itself.  But that thin shaved spray catches the wind and dreams for a moment of being sky (being air)

doesn't want to wear away at the land, slow progress, wants transubstantiation.

no, not forward.  up.

I made my own astrology the other day,
bored, at work, typifying.

Wits, born in whichever are the cold months where they are born.
Heartbreakers, in the spring, prone to shoot themselves like an arrow
and overaim.  They are often off-kilter, too, unstable with whatever they want
to settle.
Jerks (or charmers) are born in summer air too hot and dry to breathe, they
treat their own births as miracles.

This is as far as I got, I had to get back to work and forgetting 
my friends are all
witty jerks who could easily break my heart.

I promise you,
    I will not write this letter.  

            You will never know how to thank me,
                                                  Viola

like drawn 
and quartered, 
i am violent,
and simpled.

adj involving the fusion of male and female cells

v strike with a firm blow, defeat or conquer, be affected severely by a disease

n a feeling of embarrassment or distress arising from one's awareness that one has done something wrong or foolish

you sank into me like i was so many pillows,
like you found me your mother, limp-armed but alive this time, this time you were seven
but she was alive and the pills hadn't gotten to her brain and you had just
climbed into bed with her and sunk into the pillows and she'd been warm, this time,
warm like me.

you worked, i remember, to find pleasure.  it hurt you, in your face and you didn't want
to be rough with the bed, you wanted, i could see, to stay sinking, soft.

i'm still here, if you want to find her again; i'm still here.

there are no emotions for atoms,
no explanations for us -

we just turn however we turn,
stuck together,
stoic, unquestioning, complete.

Bad Start

we met for dinner, I
had cooked the whole thing:

spent the afternoon researching,
recipes (and your allergies), cleaning the pans,
letting the oven grow warm, warm, warmer,
the room sweating, my hair limping,
anticipation misting on the bottle of
 wine carefully chosen (for beef or pasta or fish or . . .)
and

places set on new place-mats bought along with the
perfume and pantyhose and I'm not a fake girl:
no mascara, no blush, lipstick (a touch)
but

should have used a microwave;
we could have laughed while popping
forks through plastic, lounged around with
socks on (legs covered, pimples out),
 sipped beer from chipped mugs, smelled
each other - I'm sorry!

meet me for leftovers?
(we can eat them cold)




                                                             No matter how far you have gone down the wrong road, turn back.
                                                                                                                                         -Turkish proverb

There's no one like a therapist,
to listen calmly when you are pissed,
to explain the logic you may have missed,
to forgive the froth and address the gist.

You sometimes need a professional,
to expose your worries as banal,
to remind you to walk when you want to crawl,
to be a mirror in which you're big, not small.

So, if you have problems you need to fix,
eschew the simple, and choose elaborate tricks,
don't lean on drugs or get stuck on sex:
a CPC will take your shit and cash your checks.

stigma:
the sticky bulb in the center of a flower;
a mark of disgrace.

it is folded inside
pages softly familiar,
and so are you.

the petals suck sunlight down in
seeping pink and, sensing this,
perhaps, you shudder.
 
tawny heat will tauten the walls,
no matter how you beat your body, your style,
against them.

stiffen up, girl:

we admire all things,
when they're open.


                                                 for Mea

Dream

when I am cold, I am a robot crushing
the necks of pups; I fear my armor cannot stop wolves.

suggest a change and I will choose rubble, but the
       quivering aspen's bark is enough rubble for me to change,
       to dissolve my metal skin, and weave through the woods to
       a stream seeping in from the city.

it is casual for me, it is human, to stop the sickly flow
      and watch you, thing of beauty,
                                                                  repel the mud.

Reality of Personality

a wreckage:

    flotsam lapping against beaches,
    rocks splintering wood,
    balloons popping into flaps,
    dictionaries without pages,

the baby's head breaking a womb.

Prayer
by Ben Hecht

Good gentlemen who overpay
Me fifty times for every fart,
Who hand me statues when I bray
And hail my whinneying as Art --
I pick your pockets every day
But how you bastards break my heart.

Knee deep in butlers, smothered half
In horse shit splendors, soft and fat
And worshipping the Golden Calf
I mutter through my new plush hat
"Why did you steal my Pilgrim's Staff?
Why do you make me write like that?"

I kowtow to you day and night
In conference I am always glad
To kiss your ass a rosey white
And wipe it with my writing pad
But when I get alone to write
Oh, gentlemen, I go half mad!

My chateaus turn sheiss house fawn,
My gardens fair stink in my nose
When sitting down I start to spawn
Those jelly fish scenarios --
Those drooling tales of Came the Dawn
And Virtue sweet beshat her foes . . .

No human beings dare intrude
Upon my plots, no truth rebuke
The moron, cretin, or the prude,
I write of servant, clerk and duke
All slobbering with platitude
And half-assed ninnies etched in puke.

My heroine must be so nice
So full of dainty tweedledums --
Her gimlet ass a cake of ice --
So delicate she feasts on crumbs
And full of smirking sacrifice
Farts bonbons and shits sugar plums.

This Venus of cliche and slop
Must nary imbecile affront,
Must suffer and come out on top,
Must love and die and bear the brunt
While Willy Hays like a traffic cop
Barks signals from inside her cunt.

And what about the dreary hick --
My hero with his marcelled hair --
So noble, cute and politic,
So winsome -- Holy God is there
In all of lit'rature a prick
As flaccid and a mind as bare.

He must be fashioned without juice
No thinking must disturb or shock
This last pale drop of self abuse --
This human cypher run amok
Whose balls are full of Mother Goose
With Bo Peep tattooed on his cock.

These are the lovers I must link
Two eunuchs panting prettily
Whom censors have forbade to drink
To fuck, to shit, to take a pee --
Just to make goo goo eyes and stink
Of cinema nobility.

But not enough that I must limn
These hypo thyroid Launcelots
And fungus headed virgin quim --
These mentally arrested tots
But must exercise their wit and whim
In what are known as Sure Fire Plots.

Who envies me my swimming pool,
My esne, servitor and slave
My mameluke and royal fool
And Miss Luella Parson's rave --
That one has never played the ghoul
At every mildewed drama's grave.

Has never dallied with the bones
Of long dead tales or tried to woo
A zombie plot-turn from its stones --
Has never poured his soul into
Cadavers or retyped the moans
Of corpses for a camera crew.

Good Gentlemen I only trace
With cautious word the horrid chore,
The tribulation that I face
In playing literary whore --
That little nuance of disgrace
That one gets so much money for . . .

Yet hear my prayer -- the timid plea
That trickles from my venal bed,
The echo of integrity
That still wails in my empty head.
Attend!  And please don't fire me
For not being altogether dead.

O Molochs of the Movie Set
O Geniuses who violence
Has tamed the Lion for a pet,
O Mighty Wizards who dispense
Amusement to the world -- please let
Me write a movie that makes sense.

Before I die or go berserk
Oh let me write once Not To Fit
Some big box office movie jerk
Some million dollar piece of tit,
Oh let my battered talents work
On something besides baby shit.

Oh let me grow one leaf of grass,
One breath of truth, one cry of man's
Travail and quest, one peal of brass
To drive Art from its crapping cans --
One tale that doesn't kiss the ass
Of ninety million movie fans.

The Stroke

it was the spinal snap of chopsticks;
the birth of a body and a mind.

To His Last Lover

I see you as air popping out
of a sinking body - arid pockets,
useless as questions,
                                    collapsing.

life is an Old World fairy tale,
but perhaps you did not know:

it is foolish to trust a corpse
to the sea
                   when there is magic all
around.

you were the last breaths
of a drowning man; but, my
dear, I

I have grown him gills.

it is so full, the sea - such a
lithe cyan thickness, a breathing
shell. 

slippery, but not wet,
we are rocked
to sleep by the moon, and I

can only hope,
for his sake, that you

are enjoying 
your air -
                  all that 

common
            sticky
                 empty.

In My Own Defense

I'm sorry, Leonard, that I cannot be constant,
like you.

maybe it it because I am a woman,

(a swelling moon, a starving moon)

the muscle of a torn grape, or nothing.

who could walk straight with an
undulating body?  what brain
can be calm in a dry oatmeal skull?

To Be Written Of
 
you, my dear, are blessed with that magnet:
the antimagnet.

that which has nothing to do with you stirs
when you walk by;

the world knows
incongruity suits you.

walking by me in the world's wardrobe, you wilt
skin off muscle off bone off marrow - I can be

such a stripped stem, parched 

for what breeds on you 
free and easy
as dew.

The accident has occurred,
the ship has broken, the motor
of the car has failed, we have been
separated from the others,
we are alone in the sand, the ocean,
the frozen snow

I remember what I have to do
in order to stay alive,
I take stock of our belongings
most of them useless

I know I should be digging shelters,
killing seabirds and making
clothes from their feathers,
cutting the rinds from cacti, chewing
roots for water, scraping through
the ice for treebark, for moss

but I rest here without power
to save myself, tasting
salt in my mouth, the fact that
you won't save me

watching the mirage of us
hands locked, smiling,
as it fades into the white desert.

I touch you, straighten the sheet, you turn over
in the bed, tender
sun comes through the curtains

Which of us will survive
which of us will survive the other

I can change my-
self more easily
than I can change you

I could grow bark and
become a shrub

or switch back in time
to the woman image left
in cave rubble, the drowned
stomach bulbed with fertility,
face a tiny bead, a
lump, queen of the termites

or (better) speed myself up,
disguise myself in the knuckles
and purple-veined veils of old ladies,
become arthritic and genteel

or one twist further:
collapse across your
bed clutching my heart
and pull the nostalgic sheet up over
my waxed farewell smile

which would be inconvenient
but final.

Affair

there is no proof.

no time-stamps, no
official seals, the wax
unmelted, the royal rings still
on fingers.

we are pixels of color
       too small to see, we are
little invisible lines
in space.  I know, but

I cannot confirm, us.

no he&i-shaped light 
leaked onto 
chemical-treated paper, no
love-letters on
parchment tied with ribbons,
and yellowing.

I can find no proof.

my eyes go white from searching;

just then his
head hits my shoulder like

ink hitting paper and

it's a long silent ride home
while a surveillance camera 
takes recordings of us I will never see, 

but
at least I know

are there.

it's okay if you've looked at me enough;
I've been the same for years: a pegasus,

arches of gold.  no one needs
to be reminded of a classic.

but I can see out of these static eyes; I can
watch without blinking.

I only want to look at you because
they designed me to always
be that way.

always needing to stare, I can stare in a mirror
if I need to be seen.

Suits

I should take the hearts; my bleeding started today.
my flushed inviting curves reduced to a sharpened reddened point.

you should take the spades; you've been jealous.
digging to expose what is hidden, find the buried and replace it with seeds.

distribute the clubs randomly, neither of us has used
that blunt heavy-handedness (the one that deadens as it keeps us
grounded) recently.

split the diamonds:
 we are both cut and cutting,  each shining
selves produced by friction,
and coveted.

however dealt, we'll end the day
in bed,
limb on limb on limb.

two halves of a deck, midshuffle.

Glue


i.
the rain won't fall; see it
just clings to the glass

like button candy. these drops
couldn't possibly fall, and not

take with them
little wisps of window.


ii.
my many hearts are lined up
in rows - red, 
       yellow, blue - sweet looking
but

I can never give one away

without a bit
of that white madness.

I keep telling the usual
little places about who loves
who --

with sticks sheathed into wet sand
and
dragged,

brick shards chipped
onto grey concrete and
scraped,

metal points dug
under tree bark
                      and
           twisted.

I suffer from lack of time;

always easier to say
the short version,
and be satisfied,

if it hurts
someone.

A Tear
for E.D., that bitch.

a Snail crawled out - my Eye,
made a wet little tickle; paused.

made another, moving down,
moving over - my Skin.

it didn't know how snails go
so it went - one twitch at a time -
teasing pores on either side -
some kind of forward,
down.

a Snail crawled to my Mouth;
it didn't know where lips go,
so it Stuck.

I showed where snails that don't know
how snails go go:

I bit,

and chewed until I knew I was tasting
a Goo that, too, Knew, but shelled

itself in Stickings.

D.
 
i.

I love you as one does the beach:

beyond division and enumeration of, 
              within the simple meeting of, 
                                                                   sands and seas.
 
 
ii.

must I name each grain to be sure I write it all,
and ignore the drying seaweed, 
the dead things, cigarette butts?

gradations from when you are wet with tears,
                   hard and full, and
                              when you are lumpy with footsteps,
                   hot and dry - is it they
       that can say -
how you fill me end to end?

and the periphery!  what must be told
of waves, clouds, and highways -
to ensure you know how you shine
                          against the world
        when you lay under me,
                  just so?

iii.
 
the sliding wind of time takes you
under sharpened stakes,
dripping bodies,
gulls and litter and dogs, the dampening
of a plush orange sky,
       restless pushing waters

to a night of melting ice, where I,
the single silhouetted figure . . . am

able to dance, and do dance,
with the shredding edges of the world,

since I have you to stand on.

Writing my poems is like shaving my legs:

I have known I should do it for days, I have taken tweezers to the particularly dark ones
and long ones, and one growing in pairs or triads,
or any that threaten to grow backwards or any
that just . . . annoy me.

I try to force some out with my fingernails, but
they resist, they leave marks,
they are failures that may not ever heal.

And so it is a rough patch left - the ones that grew in
easy and modest, the ones I barely knew were there,
but now I see them and should prune them.

This takes preparation - relaxation or, rather,
exhaustion by means of steaming wetnesses,
slow openings and vulnerabilities met
with sharpened blades.

I have never used cream, but never had
a problem bleeding, either.

When I'm done, the wetness gone,
I wash what's left off the sides and swirling
drown the drain,

where they belong.

Andrew

i.
to be nice:
he was too smart for his own good.

his room littered with impossibly intricate art that now
seem like mirrors instead, and he in the middle,
wherever the middle was,
holding the twine and urging you to go on, go on

into the maze.

ii.
some women have eggs in them that hatch ravens,
not breasts, and forever hear the fluttering of
wings without flying.

grounded, they walk on tiptoes, always on the verge of
taking off and always standing
above the crowd.

those were his type - the awkward ones with full heads
yearning for the sky, and yet if you broke open his
mind you would see a thousand tiny white skeletons

of crippled baby birds.


iii.
a stiff green teardrop, life was beginning to bloom
a dozen different petals and there was vulnerability,
persistent flies, and color, so much subtle hidden color.

I screamed a hazy orange, mostly, spit out all my hues in waves
upon waves and thought I might never open more but he
was a white fly, unimpressed.
